question.text: In a typical Mendelian cross which is a dihybrid cross, one parent is homozygous for both dominant traits and another parent is homozygous for both recessive traits. In the <math><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> generation, both parental combinations and recombinations appear. The phenotypic ratio of parental combinations to recombinations, is

solution.text: A cross of round yellow seeds (both dominant) and green wrinkled seed (both recessive) plants produced 9 : 3 : 3 : 1 ratio of plants (phenotypic) in <math><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> generation. The ratio of parental to recombinant is 10 : 6 here because the 9 and 1 are of parental type and 3 and 3 are recombinant.
